headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Certainly, In terms of used in the fourth quarter, as we mentioned, we grew 4% and have seen some acceleration from the second quarter. We're very focused on our inventory levels and getting our inventory levels up to where we want to be going
componenttext: Yes, sure. Certainly, In terms of used in the fourth quarter, as we mentioned, we grew 4% and have seen some acceleration from the second quarter. We're very focused on our inventory levels and getting our inventory levels up to where we want to be going in the holiday. As we've said before on this call, we have a lot of history. We know how well the ramp runs and want to make sure we're ready. So we feel good about that. In terms of margin expectations, 46% to 49% is what we've quoted is our margin expectation and that's consistent. We've not experienced impacts from competitors. We know that there's -- we've had lots of discussions with lots of people on that. And we're very focused on running our play, which as you know has very significant hurdles for our competitors around pricing, balancing, refurbishment, pawnshop legislation. So buy-sell-trade will again be our primary value driver for the consumer in the holiday, and we don't see any reason to change that expectation.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Colin, in terms of the digital quantification, we understand the need to quantify that and begin to articulate that. We aren't prepared to do that at this time, but we are discussing internally how we will quantify that with you. And we will have more to
componenttext: Colin, in terms of the digital quantification, we understand the need to quantify that and begin to articulate that. We aren't prepared to do that at this time, but we are discussing internally how we will quantify that with you. And we will have more to talk about on our next release.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Part of this, Colin, is understanding what the hybrid behavior is of the consumer. As Tony mentioned, we're seeing consumers -- what's happening at GameStop now, people who've never bought DLC, moms, dads grandparents, are getting introduced to digital co
componenttext: Part of this, Colin, is understanding what the hybrid behavior is of the consumer. As Tony mentioned, we're seeing consumers -- what's happening at GameStop now, people who've never bought DLC, moms, dads grandparents, are getting introduced to digital content. People who've never seen what a free-to-play game platform looks like are getting introduced to it. So we're changing the consumer behavior. And part of our mission I think is to understand that behavior and how we report it and measure it.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what we are seeing as a multichannel consumer is a larger consumer of gaming overall. So we're seeing that trend as well.
componenttext: And what we are seeing as a multichannel consumer is a larger consumer of gaming overall. So we're seeing that trend as well.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gary Balter from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gary Balter from Credit Suisse.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: One is, as we look at the Christmas season, you had mentioned in the past that Map isn't on the Wii and I guess anything made by Nintendo on that. What do you see the impact of that? And without disclosing your promotional strategies, does that leave more
componenttext: One is, as we look at the Christmas season, you had mentioned in the past that Map isn't on the Wii and I guess anything made by Nintendo on that. What do you see the impact of that? And without disclosing your promotional strategies, does that leave more opportunity to be selective with some of the promotions?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think a couple of things. If you look at last year, what happened in the promotional environment, we actually gained share and held serve on a lot of the action titles that were promoted and marked down in the channel, which tells you that our ability t
componenttext: I think a couple of things. If you look at last year, what happened in the promotional environment, we actually gained share and held serve on a lot of the action titles that were promoted and marked down in the channel, which tells you that our ability to provide value and service and assortment in-store is worth a certain amount of value to the consumer. If you look at marked-down hardware, we know that that's one where the big boxes can have a pretty big impact. If you talk about Map not being applied, we are expecting all kinds of promotions around that and are planning for it and have a healthy allocation of product going into holiday and will run our play accordingly. And in terms of value, it's important to remember buy-sell trade is -- all our consumer work tells us buy-sell-trade is the highest value proposition, even more than discounts, because we can bring trade credits to consumers, over $1 billion of trade credits. So we'll be using that to deal with whatever happens in the promotional area.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Second question, the PowerUp Rewards which you talked about earlier on the call. How sticky do you sense that that's making some of your customers, because that's a great tool. It's not matched by some of your competitors.
componenttext: Second question, the PowerUp Rewards which you talked about earlier on the call. How sticky do you sense that that's making some of your customers, because that's a great tool. It's not matched by some of your competitors.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're exactly right, Gary. The behavior of PowerUp has surprised us. If you remember our 2Q call, we were kind of surprised by what our pilot market showed us when we started in May, and we chose to accelerate. One of the reasons is, we're seeing consume
componenttext: You're exactly right, Gary. The behavior of PowerUp has surprised us. If you remember our 2Q call, we were kind of surprised by what our pilot market showed us when we started in May, and we chose to accelerate. One of the reasons is, we're seeing consumers far stickier than we thought they would they be. We're not ready to talk about all of that for competitive reasons but when we say that people are shopping 3x the frequency, we're really seeing a subset shop has even far more than that. So we're seeing consumers in what is a price parity category, right, because the category is generally all the same price. Giving consumers one more reason to turn left into GameStop instead of right into a big box has turned out to be a very powerful thing. The other thing that's happening, Gary, is our ability to communicate individually with consumers based on their game library has become a very powerful marketing effort. We are seeing a lot of productivity from those unique recommendations we're making in those unique messages. In fact, Tony talked about our DLC launch. That's available only to PowerUp Rewards members, because we're going to communicate with them through our encrypted site at poweruprewards.com. So lots of interesting sticky opportunities for that consumer.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, another source of stickiness through PowerUp Rewards, as we used that to market to our consumers and send them to kongregate.com, we find that those consumers have come from PowerUp Rewards register at a much higher rate on kongregate.com than any o
componenttext: Gary, another source of stickiness through PowerUp Rewards, as we used that to market to our consumers and send them to kongregate.com, we find that those consumers have come from PowerUp Rewards register at a much higher rate on kongregate.com than any other customers coming. So we also see stickiness on our expanded areas of growth, not just in our stores.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just last question, you mentioned again the return on invested capital. Could you quantify kind of how we should think about that, like what the buyback will be going forward? Because you're generating so much cash each year. And the other drivers, like h
componenttext: Just last question, you mentioned again the return on invested capital. Could you quantify kind of how we should think about that, like what the buyback will be going forward? Because you're generating so much cash each year. And the other drivers, like how much of that do you think will come from just repurchasing stock? And how much will come from other drivers, just operationally?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, I'm not sure that we're in a position to break down how much of that 400-basis-point improvement that we've talked about will come from buyback versus other initiatives. But rest assured that within our plans, that sort of controlled growth that we'
componenttext: Gary, I'm not sure that we're in a position to break down how much of that 400-basis-point improvement that we've talked about will come from buyback versus other initiatives. But rest assured that within our plans, that sort of controlled growth that we've talked about in our store base where we can get market share and achieve desired returns, as well as the initiatives that we're investing in, in loyalty and digital and e-commerce, will drive ROIC. And then obviously, debt and stock repurchase can drive ROIC.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Arvind Bhatia from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Arvind Bhatia from Sterne Agee.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of housekeeping questions. First on new store openings, what they were this quarter just to get a net number. And then you talked about recently next year you plan to have or go forward you want to have 2% to 3% net store growth. Can you tell us,
componenttext: A couple of housekeeping questions. First on new store openings, what they were this quarter just to get a net number. And then you talked about recently next year you plan to have or go forward you want to have 2% to 3% net store growth. Can you tell us, 2011 what you're thinking gross store openings? And then second quick one is what was the stock compensation expense in the third quarter? And what is the full year share count that you guys are expecting?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the latter couple of questions. The stock compensation expense in the third quarter was approximately $10.6 million. And we expect the full year share count to be approximately $153 million to $154 million. And then your questions were o
componenttext: Let me start with the latter couple of questions. The stock compensation expense in the third quarter was approximately $10.6 million. And we expect the full year share count to be approximately $153 million to $154 million. And then your questions were on the number of openings. And obviously, we disclosed in the release what the net openings were. Year-to-date, so far, we've had 238 openings and 82 closings. In the quarter, we opened 78 stores and closed 21. Our expectations for next year are between 300 and 400 store openings and between 100 and 200 store closings.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on used margins this quarter being strong, I think part of that you said was international. What was the trend in used margins within the domestic numbers? Did that number also go up?
componenttext: Just a quick one on used margins this quarter being strong, I think part of that you said was international. What was the trend in used margins within the domestic numbers? Did that number also go up?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're not disclosing what the margins were domestically versus internationally on a specific basis. I think directionally with the international guidance we gave, we're trying to convey to you that what we've talked about for three or four quarters in a r
componenttext: We're not disclosing what the margins were domestically versus internationally on a specific basis. I think directionally with the international guidance we gave, we're trying to convey to you that what we've talked about for three or four quarters in a row now, which is driving out those best practices to improve margins is gaining traction and we're seeing the results that we were hoping to see from that.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the increase wasn't all international, right? The domestic margins weren't any -- there wasn't any change in the trend there? Is that fair to say?
componenttext: But the increase wasn't all international, right? The domestic margins weren't any -- there wasn't any change in the trend there? Is that fair to say?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair to say. But again, I don't want to get into specifics.
componenttext: I think that's fair to say. But again, I don't want to get into specifics.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 2% to 4% comp in the fourth quarter, could you help us understand how you break that down domestic versus international?
componenttext: The 2% to 4% comp in the fourth quarter, could you help us understand how you break that down domestic versus international?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, as Mike stated in his remarks, our expectation is for positive same-store sales within our four operating segments.
componenttext: I think, as Mike stated in his remarks, our expectation is for positive same-store sales within our four operating segments.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Magee from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Magee from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. One is on the PowerUp side. How difficult will it be to get adoption among the non-core gamers out there with that? Is that something that you can do? It seems like getting those customers to be more sticky during the holidays will
componenttext: A couple of questions. One is on the PowerUp side. How difficult will it be to get adoption among the non-core gamers out there with that? Is that something that you can do? It seems like getting those customers to be more sticky during the holidays will be a big opportunity.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. This is Paul. How difficult will it be? I mean, interesting. I think we shared this with some of you on meetings, but we've had an Edge card at GameStop for a long time, very successful program but it was focused on only the Used business
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. This is Paul. How difficult will it be? I mean, interesting. I think we shared this with some of you on meetings, but we've had an Edge card at GameStop for a long time, very successful program but it was focused on only the Used business. One of the things that we have been surprised by that we've disclosed previously is 70% of our paid PowerUp pro members were incremental to the Edge card. And what that means is, we are bringing in a lot of new people to the paid membership. And the way that looks when you're in a store, we're seeing a lot of moms, dads, grandparents, gift buyers, people who would not be our core Edge customer, would not be people who previously had shopped us in used, would not people who previously received our Game Informer magazine. So we are very encouraged by the incremental nature of PowerUp Rewards, both pro and free. And find that it's bringing in a lot of people who weren't aware of GameStop's buy-sell-trade, for example, and you know that all the customer work says the more awareness we get of buy-sell-trade with the consumer, the more loyal they become because it brings value into the equation, et cetera. And so I would say all of those dynamics are pointing in the right direction for holiday for us.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then secondly, with regard to DLC over the next couple of years, I guess sort of in a qualitative way, is it possible to expect that you all could approach the same share there as you have on the retail side for the new product and see some margins over t
componenttext: Then secondly, with regard to DLC over the next couple of years, I guess sort of in a qualitative way, is it possible to expect that you all could approach the same share there as you have on the retail side for the new product and see some margins over time with that business?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tony, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Yes, Tony, do you want to take that?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We definitely do see that as we begin to launch DLC like we are launching major titles, we definitely believe that our share would grow as we have unique content, as we have a pre-order campaign, as we continue to take the fiction out of the process and i
componenttext: We definitely do see that as we begin to launch DLC like we are launching major titles, we definitely believe that our share would grow as we have unique content, as we have a pre-order campaign, as we continue to take the fiction out of the process and increase discoverability of DLC. We absolutely believe that we will approach and maybe even surpass the share that we have currently on boxed product. In terms of margins, as we stated earlier, we do plan that we will have margins that are similar to the game margins on the DLC.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And trade credits will also begin to flow into that category that have never been there before, so that's another tailwind.
componenttext: And trade credits will also begin to flow into that category that have never been there before, so that's another tailwind.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have time for two more questions. Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: We have time for two more questions. Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just had a quick question, just following up on used sales in the quarter. I guess when you reported second quarter results, you guided to 7% to 9%. You said, look, we're getting back into inventory on used. And sales I mean, they improved sequentially, b
componenttext: Just had a quick question, just following up on used sales in the quarter. I guess when you reported second quarter results, you guided to 7% to 9%. You said, look, we're getting back into inventory on used. And sales I mean, they improved sequentially, but they were only up 4%. So I guess I was wondering what was sort of the disconnect between what you guided to and sales only being up 4%.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Anthony, I think what Paul talked about in his comments was that the new game buyer was stronger than we expected in the quarter. So as we talked about last quarter, the strength of the new brings in the trade and then sets us up for the used. And with al
componenttext: Anthony, I think what Paul talked about in his comments was that the new game buyer was stronger than we expected in the quarter. So as we talked about last quarter, the strength of the new brings in the trade and then sets us up for the used. And with all the titles that came out in September and October, we continued to see strength in the new and haven't sort of hit that tipping point yet where the used consumer kicks in to the extent that we expect it.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So to some extent, new is a little bit stronger than you thought and that sort of took away from used? Is that a fair assessment?
componenttext: So to some extent, new is a little bit stronger than you thought and that sort of took away from used? Is that a fair assessment?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a fair assessment.
componenttext: That's a fair assessment.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your last question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong from CL King & Associates.
componenttext: And your last question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong from CL King & Associates.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The DLC that you're offering in stores now, are these just for Sony and Microsoft published titles? Or do you have DLC from third parties, like EA and Activision?
componenttext: The DLC that you're offering in stores now, are these just for Sony and Microsoft published titles? Or do you have DLC from third parties, like EA and Activision?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, you want to answer that?
componenttext: Tony, you want to answer that?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of our deals actually come from third-party publishers. Definitely right now, we have Microsoft rolled out in all of our stores, and Sony is being rolled out in all of our stores in the U.S. at this point. But what we have is a wide assortment and wh
componenttext: Most of our deals actually come from third-party publishers. Definitely right now, we have Microsoft rolled out in all of our stores, and Sony is being rolled out in all of our stores in the U.S. at this point. But what we have is a wide assortment and where we are now with Microsoft and where we will be soon with Sony is as new DLC comes out from any publisher, we will be offering that at the same time that it is available for Xbox live users or PSN users so that we can offer it in our store. That gives us the opportunity to allow for pre-order and allow for pre-marketing of that like we do with major titles and then deliver it digitally to our PowerUp Rewards members. So it is a full assortment of DLC that is available. We also have invested lots of money in our POS system and our guides that are in our stores so that we actually recommend automatically DLC with both new and used games and have DLC available.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it's a full assortment of titles of that are for the Sony and Microsoft platform?
componenttext: So it's a full assortment of titles of that are for the Sony and Microsoft platform?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about Nintendo?
componenttext: How about Nintendo?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nintendo right now, at this point, we are in discussions with Nintendo on this, obviously. And I think that we will continue to have those conversations at this point. We don't have a plan or a road map with them in the first half of next year that would
componenttext: Nintendo right now, at this point, we are in discussions with Nintendo on this, obviously. And I think that we will continue to have those conversations at this point. We don't have a plan or a road map with them in the first half of next year that would put them in our stores, but it's definitely something we continue to talk with them as they evolve their digital strategy. I think we have a great retail environment that will be ready to accommodate their retail strategy when it becomes more developed.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving on to the international sales, obviously, were weak and I assume Europe led the way there. How was Canada and how was Australia and New Zealand relevant to the overall international performance?
componenttext: Moving on to the international sales, obviously, were weak and I assume Europe led the way there. How was Canada and how was Australia and New Zealand relevant to the overall international performance?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, would you want take that?
componenttext: Mike, would you want take that?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Really not prepared to break it out by region at the moment. But as we said, hardware declined more than expected, but actually new software and new software grew versus prior years. So it's a good mix change for us.
componenttext: Sure. Really not prepared to break it out by region at the moment. But as we said, hardware declined more than expected, but actually new software and new software grew versus prior years. So it's a good mix change for us.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you say fourth quarter you expect positive comps, overall, does that mean within all four regions or not necessarily?
componenttext: And when you say fourth quarter you expect positive comps, overall, does that mean within all four regions or not necessarily?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't want to break out the comps by region. But internationally, if you combine the three regions, we expect positive comps due to the strong slated new releases.
componenttext: I wouldn't want to break out the comps by region. But internationally, if you combine the three regions, we expect positive comps due to the strong slated new releases.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question, just housekeeping. On the tax rate for Q4, what should we be modeling for that?
componenttext: And then last question, just housekeeping. On the tax rate for Q4, what should we be modeling for that?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You should be modeling something consistent with maybe a little higher than last year for Q4.
componenttext: You should be modeling something consistent with maybe a little higher than last year for Q4.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Something like 37%, 38%, around there?
componenttext: Something like 37%, 38%, around there?

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's reasonable, yes.
componenttext: That's reasonable, yes.

headline: GameStop Corp., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for attending today's call. Have a great Thanksgiving. Have a great holiday season. And please come and visit GameStop for all your gaming needs and join our new PowerUp Rewards program. We want you in our program. And come to GameStop, wh
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for attending today's call. Have a great Thanksgiving. Have a great holiday season. And please come and visit GameStop for all your gaming needs and join our new PowerUp Rewards program. We want you in our program. And come to GameStop, where you have the best service, the best selection and the greatest value, convenient locations, et cetera, et cetera. So thank you very much.
